facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 800 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 800 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated March 30, 1964 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 27 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1964, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 27 of 1964.

facts.text: Appellant is holder of contract carriage permit granted by Regional Transport Authority, Agra, valid till February 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who appeals by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Allahabad dated March 30, 1964 is the holder of a companytract carriage permit granted to him by the Regional Transport Authority, Agra and valid till February 1, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant owns a single contract carriage.

anchor.surface_text: He owns a single companytract carriage and his permit companyers the whole of the Agra region

facts.text: Permit covers whole Agra region comprising six districts: Mathura, Agra, Aligarh, Etah, Etawah and Mainpuri.

anchor.surface_text: and his permit companyers the whole of the Agra region which companyprises the six districts of Mathura, Agra, Aligarh, Etah, Etawah and Mainpuri.

facts.text: No special route or routes indicated in appellant's permit; terminals are frontiers of the region on all sides.

anchor.surface_text: No special route or routes are indicated in his permit and the terminal of his operation are the frontiers of this region on all sides.

facts.text: In 1955, Government of Uttar Pradesh framed scheme for nationalisation under S. 3 of U. P. Road Transport Services Development Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, the Government of Uttar Pradesh, purporting to act under S. 3 of the U. P. Road Transport Services  Development  Act, 1955, framed a scheme for nationalisation of transport services in Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: 1955 scheme struck down by Allahabad High Court on petition of some private operators.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme which was then framed was struck down by an order of the High Court of Allahabad on the petition of some private operators.

facts.text: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 amended by introduction of Chapter IVA by Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 effective February 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 was amended by the introduction of Chapter IVA dealing with special provisions relating to State Transport Undertakings. This amendment was introduced by the Motor Vehicles  Amendment  Act, 1956 with effect from February 16, 1957.

facts.text: After amendment, scheme reconsidered by State Government and action taken under Chapter IVA, s.68C.

anchor.surface_text: After the amending Act the scheme was reconsidered by the State Government and action was taken under Chapter IVA to numberify it under s. 68C of the Motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: Scheme notified 56 routes removed from operation of contract carriage permits of private operators in Agra region.

anchor.surface_text: In this scheme 56 routes, which were mentioned by name, were removed from the operation of companytract carriage permits issued to private operators in the Agra region

facts.text: Government announced adequate State Road Transport contract carriage services on those 56 routes or portions thereof.

anchor.surface_text: and Government announced that adequate State Road Transport companytract carriage services would be provided on those routes or portions thereof.

facts.text: Functioning of transport services other than State Road Transport Services prohibited on those 56 routes.

anchor.surface_text: The functioning of transport services other than those put by the State Road Transport Services was prohibited on all those routes.

facts.text: Scheme published in Gazette on October 17, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: but their objections were over-ruled and the scheme was published in the Gazette on October 17, 1959.

facts.text: Appellant and others filed Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 26622 of 1959 objecting to the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: A writ petition  Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 26622 of 1959  was filed by the appellant and others objecting to the scheme on various grounds.

facts.text: Writ petition allowed on February 1, 1962 by Mr. Justice Oak; scheme set aside and remanded for reconsideration.

anchor.surface_text: This was allowed on February 1, 1962 by Mr. Justice Oak who set aside the scheme and remanded it for reconsideration in the light of his order.

facts.text: Scheme struck down in full but only partially in respect of the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme was number struck dawn in full but only partially in respect of the petitioners in the High Court.

facts.text: State Government at liberty to enforce scheme in other respects.

anchor.surface_text: It was ordered, however, that the State Government would be at liberty to enforce the scheme in other respects.

facts.text: Reason for striking down scheme for petitioners: their objections not considered and no reasonable opportunity to produce evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The main reason for striking down the scheme in respect of those petitioners was that their objections were number companysidered and they were number given a reasonable opportunity to produce evidence in support of their objections.

facts.text: After remand, objections considered; order passed by Legal Remembrancer on October 18, 1963 reaffirming scheme overruling objections.

anchor.surface_text: After remand objections were companysidered and an order was passed by the Legal Remembrance on October 18, 1963 by which the scheme was reaffirmed over-ruling the objections.

facts.text: Change in scheme: provision of 16 contract carriage services or more or less according to need instead of adequate services.

anchor.surface_text: The only change made was that instead of the provision of adequate companytract carriage service by the State Road Transport Contract Carriage Services it was provided that 1 6 companytract carriage services or more or less in accordance with the need from time to time would be provided on the routes or portion thereof which were numberified.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition in High Court challenging the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a petition in the High Court challenging the scheme.

facts.text: Petition heard by Mr. Justice Broome and rejected on March 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It was heard by Mr. Justice Broome and rejected by him on March 17, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant filed special appeal under Letters Patent against Justice Broome's decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a special appeal under the Letters Patent against the decision of Mr. Justice Broome.

facts.text: High Court dismissed special appeal summarily by impugned order dated March 30, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by the impugned order dismissed it summarily though it passed a fairly detailed order.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1964, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 27 of 1964.
A writ petition  Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 26622 of 1959  was filed by the appellant and others objecting to the scheme on various grounds.

In 1955, the Government of Uttar Pradesh, purporting to act under S. 3 of the U. P. Road Transport Services  Development  Act, 1955, framed a scheme for nationalisation of transport services in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a special appeal under the Letters Patent against the decision of Mr. Justice Broome.

issues.text: Whether the scheme purporting to be under s. 68C satisfied the requirements of that section despite being the unchanged scheme originally framed under s. 3 of the U.P. Act?

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of Mr. G. S. Pathak is that although the scheme purports to be under s. 68C of the Motor Vehicles Act, the requirements of that section were not borne in mind inasmuch as the scheme framed under s. 3 of the U.P.

issues.text: Whether the provision for '16 contract carriages or more or less' in clause 3 of the scheme satisfies the requirement of 'adequate' service under s. 68C?

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that the provision of 16 contract carriages or more or less under cl. 3 of the present scheme does not carry out s. 68C either in spirit or in terms. Section 68C requires adequate services to be maintained and the fixing of 16 carriages in advance, it is said, does not carry out the purpose of that provision.

issues.text: Whether a scheme under s. 68C can validly curtail an area-based contract carriage permit by excluding specific routes rather than an area?

anchor.surface_text: The last contention is the most serious of all. It is submitted that the scheme is not properly framed because it provides for the operation of contract carriages on certain routes to the exclusion of the appellant who holds a permit for an area irrespective of any route or routes.

arguments.claim: The scheme does not satisfy requirements of s.68C Motor Vehicles Act because it was originally framed under s.3 U.P. Road Transport Services Development Act without change and the requirements of the two provisions differ

holdings.text: we find numberdifficulty in holding that as the requirements are basically the same, the exercise of power must be referred to s. 68c under which it has validity, and number to s. 3 of the U.P. Act

anchor.surface_text: Even if they were number and only the requirements of the U.P. Act were borne in mind, we find numberdifficulty in holding that as the requirements are basically the same, the exercise of power must be referred to s. 68c under which it has validity, and number to s. 3 of the U.P. Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance of requirements under s.3 U.P. Act and s.68C identical despite verbiage difference; scheme uses s.68C language like 'adequate'; power exercises validity under s.68C

holdings.text: We read the scheme as providing sixteen companytract carriages. We need number companysider whether it would become inadequate in the future. At the moment it is stated that 16 carriages will be provided and it is number affirmed that this number is in any way inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that on the former occasion the provision about adequate carriages was challenged as too vague. It is because of that challenge that the number of carriages is number shown and it is provided that this number may be more or less as the occasion demands. We read the scheme as providing sixteen companytract carriages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior vagueness challenge to 'adequate' led to specifying 16, currently adequate; future changes not grounds for invalidity now

holdings.text: In our judgment, the argument of the respondents must be accepted. If under S. 51 (2) a permit for a companytract carriage could be limited to specified route or routes notwithstanding that the petition for such a permit must be for an area there is no difficulty in accepting a scheme which cuts down the area by subtracting a few routes.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 68F when the permits are issued to a State transport undertaking for stage carriages or contract carriages it is provided that the Regional Transport Authority may modify the terms of any existing permit so as to curtail the area or route covered by the permit in so far as such permit relates to the notified area or notified route.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.51(2) authorizes route limits on contract carriage permits applied for area; scheme subtracting routes validly curtails area; supported by s.68B override and s.68F modification power

holdings.text: Under S. 68B the provisions of Chapter IVA apply notwithstanding anything inconsistent contained in Chapter IV of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 68B the provisions of Chapter IVA apply notwithstanding anything inconsistent contained in Chapter IV of the Act. Sections 46 to 49 are in Chapter IV and no inconsistency between a scheme framed under S. 68C and any provision of Chapter IV

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory override of Chapter IV by Chapter IVA prevents inconsistency challenges to s.68C schemes

holdings.text: The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that by the numberified scheme the routes which were mentioned must be taken to have been subtracted from the area to which the permit applied. In other words, there is numbermerit in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The taking over of certain routes exclusively for the State undertakings renders that portion of the area ineffective for a private operator such as the appellant who holds a permit for the whole area including those routes. The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that by the notified scheme the routes which were mentioned must be taken to have been subtracted from the area to which the permit applied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Route exclusion under scheme effectively curtails area permit; affirms High Court; appeal dismissed

The Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  , Subba Rao I., observed Under s. 68C of the Act the scheme may be framed in respect of any area or a route or a portion of any area or a portion of a route. There is numberinherent inconsis-  1 1962 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 717  2  A.I.R. 1961 S.C. 82.  3  1961 1 S.C.R. 642 at 664.

precedents.case_name: Dosa Satyanarayanamurty etc. v. The Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: Under s. 68C of the Act the scheme may be framed in respect of any area or a route or a portion of any area or a portion of a route. There is no inherent inconsistency between an area and a route. The proposed route is also an area limited to the route proposed
precedents.cited_holding: The proposed route is also an area limited to the route proposed. The scheme may as well propose to operate a transport service in respect of a new route from point A to point B and that route would certainly be an area within the meaning of s. 68C.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal has no merit; High Court judgment upheld; nationalisation scheme valid

anchor.surface_text: under s. 68F when the permits are issued to a State transport undertaking for stage carriages or contract carriages it is provided that the Regional Transport Authority may modify the terms of any existing permit so as to curtail the area or route covered by the permit in so far as such permit relates to the notified area or notified route.

under s. 68F when the permits are issued to a State transport undertaking for stage carriages or contract carriages it is provided that the Regional Transport Authority may modify the terms of any existing permit so as to curtail the area or route covered by the permit in so far as such permit relates to the notified area or notified route.

Under S. 68B the provisions of Chapter IVA apply notwithstanding anything inconsistent contained in Chapter IV of the Act. Sections 46 to 49 are in Chapter IV and no inconsistency between a scheme framed under S. 68C and any provision of Chapter IV

The taking over of certain routes exclusively for the State undertakings renders that portion of the area ineffective for a private operator such as the appellant who holds a permit for the whole area including those routes. The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that by the notified scheme the routes which were mentioned must be taken to have been subtracted from the area to which the permit applied.
